subject: Re: [junit] Introductory JUnit questions
msgSnippet: ... True. Nearly every testing and building tool out there finds all tests automatically. ... In the main method you would use
messageBody:
Michael wrote on 11.8.2011 18:17:
> 1. It seems that since NB has built-in JUnit support (i.e. Run File), I
> don't need to have an associated Main class under the Test Packages.
> True or false?

True. Nearly every testing and building tool out there finds all tests
automatically.


> 2. If I do decide to use a Main class as my test harness for my JUnit
> classes, I assume I have to declare an instance of the test class. True
> or false?
>
> 3. Furthermore, if I were to instantiate the test class and run it under
> my Main, wouldn't I basically have to make a call to each test* method
> explicitly? It seems like "Run File" does that for me.

In the main method you would use
http://junit.sourceforge.net/javadoc/org/junit/runner/JUnitCore.html and
give it a list of all test classes (or suites which contain the test
classes). JUnit will create the test class instances itself (actually
once per test method) and call the test methods.


> 4. I was able to just do "Run File" on AngleTest.java and it ran for me
> in a split screen window at the bottom of NB. Kind of cool - gives me
> pass/fail and TTE (time to execute) stats. I noticed, however, that
> everything failed because JUnit by default puts in some boilerplate
> lines of code:

It's NetBeans (or whichever tool you used) that generates the
boilerplate, not JUnit.


> 5. Am I supposed to go ahead and customize the values and/or code in the
> auto-generated test methods to test what I want? What's the better
> approach: Add more code for more test cases inside the method, or keep
> changing the existing code and re-running it until I'm satisfied with
> the test results?

The best approach would be to write all tests manually. That way you can
write meaningful tests which describe the features of the system. See
http://blog.orfjackal.net/2010/02/three-styles-of-naming-tests.html


> 6. If I deliberately set the result and expResult to be two different
> things and also remove the call to fail(), will assertEquals() take care
> of raising a flag saying, "Hey dummy, your results didn't match!"?

Try it. (The answer should be yes.)


> 7. What happens if I set a value for the angle in degrees and make a
> call to something like setDegrees(value)? How can that even fail anyway
> (i.e. what's the point of having the test method)?

It won't fail. There is no point in testing things such as trivial
setters/getters (and language features such as the `new` operator).
Those will be tested indirectly when you write tests for features which
use them. Write tests for (all) things which could possibly fail.


> 8. If I just remove the auto-generated calls to fail() as the comment
> suggests, then how am I going to know if my test is failing or not?
> Essentially what I'm seeing is that I can rig the test however I want,
> which is not entirely what I'd like to happen.

To find out whether a test works, modify the production code so that it
has a bug in the feature which is being tested by the test. Good tests
fail: http://www.agitar.com/downloads/TheWayOfTestivus.pdf

An even better way is to write the tests before the production code.
First the test will fail because the system doesn't yet do the thing
which is specified by the test. Write code until the test passes. Remove
duplication and fix bad names
(http://www.jbrains.ca/permalink/the-four-elements-of-simple-design).
Repeat.

Here is a tutorial to get started:
https://github.com/orfjackal/tdd-tetris-tutorial


> P.S. I realize it would probably be helpful to attach both Angle.java
> and AngleTest.java. If anyone has a suggestion for what to do about
> that, I'll gladly post them. (Neither class is proprietary.)

I don't know whether this mailing list allows attachements, but whatever
the case, it's always possible to use https://gist.github.com/
http://pastebin.com/ or a similar site for sharing snippets of code.
